Title: Plate with a View of a Religious Interior
Description: The potter who decorated this plate chose to depict an architectural interior- possibly a shrine- as if it were a flat fa√ßade, with domes over the building's three principle units. The central niche probably represents a "mihrab," orienting the building to Mecca. The large lamp, rendered here in blue, is typical of traditional lighting fixtures in mosques and other religious buildings. It hangs over a low, cross-shaped bookstand intended to hold a copy of the Qur'an. The lines of what look like Arabic writing above the stand are not legible and probably were meant to imitate Qur'anic verses.
Provenance: Dikran Kelekian, Paris and New York; Henry Walters, Baltimore, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Creator: Syrian
DisplayLocation: Centre Street: Third Floor: Islamic Art
